## üî® Tool use by fishes   {{< fa tag >}} First postdoc

{{< fa globe >}} Project website: [https://fishtooluse.com](https://fishtooluse.com)

{{< fa brands instagram >}} Project instagram: [https://www.instagram.com/fishtooluse/](https://www.instagram.com/fishtooluse/)

I have been conducting a project on *anvil use by fishes* with Professor Culum Brown at the [Fish Lab](https://thefishlab.com/){target="_blank"} at Macquarie University (Sydney, Australia) since October 2022. It feels like an achievement to finally work on coral reef fish behaviour ‚Äì my long-term goal ‚Äì with the world expert on fish behaviour and cognition!

Almost nothing was known about this tool-use behaviour, so I have been collected observations using *fieldwork* and *community science*. We want to get basic knowledge of this behaviour, in addition to understand its evolutionary history and adaptive function. We also believe anvil use in fish is a good system for understanding the cognitive, ecological and morphological *factors driving the evolution of tool use* in animals. 

{{< video images/Choerodon-anchorago.mp4 alt="A Choerodon anchorago fish stricking a shell on a coral">}}

We have a side project on *social learning of tool use* in a wrasse fish species, in collaboration with a team in New-Zealand. Cyndi-Lee Harrison-Burgess conducted a lab experiment during her master‚Äôs internship and found promising evidence of social learning!

So far, I have published one paper on a subset of observations in a group of fish called the New World *Halichoeres* ([PDF available here](pdfs/TarielAdam2025.pdf){target="_blank"}). More papers are coming!

## üêå Characterising transgenerational plasticity {{< fa tag >}} PhD project
 
Some people say that you will eventually circle back to your PhD project at some point of your career, though I think it‚Äôs unlikely since I‚Äôm glad it‚Äôs behind me! This is probably because I had always wanted to work on fish behaviour and evolution, which I did end up doing for my PhD project. That said, I had two great supervisors ‚Äì √âmilien Luquet and Sandrine Pl√©net ‚Äì with whom I always enjoy interacting, as I do with everyone in the [LEHNA](https://umr5023.univ-lyon1.fr){target="_blank"} team. 

I began my PhD project at Claude Bernard Lyon 1 University (France) with a 3-month internship in 2015 and officially started in September 2017. I completed it in April 2021. During this time, I conducted two lab experiments on tiny, cute freshwater snails over multiple generations, analysed three datasets from previous experiments, and wrote a literature review ([PDF](pdfs/Tariel2020Review.pdf){target="_blank"})!

The lab experiments followed a similar a similar design: We were exposing snails to predator odours and then measuring the resulting effects on their shell morphology and behaviour, along with transgenerational effects on their offspring. We repeated this experiment to identify factors influencing the presence, magnitude and direction of these transgenerational effects. The factors we characterised included the generation that was exposed ([PDF](pdfs/Tariel2020GrandParentalEnv.pdf){target="_blank"}), the parent exposed ([PDF](pdfs/Tariel2020Sex.pdf){target="_blank"}) and the timing of exposure during development ([PDF](pdfs/Tariel2023.pdf){target="_blank"}). In the background, there was the aim of understanding how different environmental effects combine to shape the expression of anti-predator defences  ([PDF](pdfs/LuquetTariel2016.pdf){target="_blank"}). My PhD thesis is available for download ([here](pdfs/PhDThesisJTA.pdf){target="_blank"}), though it‚Äôs written in French!

![](images/Physa acuta.JPG){fig-alt="Physa acuta snail crawling on a plastic box" fig-align="center"} 

I was proud to apply my interest in and knowledge of animal personality to a project that examined whether parental exposure to predators caused snails to behave more similarly to or differently from one another ([PDF](pdfs/Tariel2020Behaviour.pdf){target="_blank"}). I also became involved in two side projects, both of which focused on transgenerational plasticity in *Physa* snails, of course! One explored the transgenerational effects at the level of gene expression ([PDF](pdfs/Dejeux2025.pdf){target="_blank"}); while the other investigated the maintenance of transgenerational plasticity after many lab generations, which is still waiting in √âmilien's computer.

As you may have noticed, four papers ended up being published in 2020, people often get confused when citing Tariel et al. 2020 ‚Äì which I completely understand! ü§™

## üê£ Brood parasistim in fish {{< fa tag >}} Master internship

In Spring 2015, I had the privilege to meet and work with one of my favourite researchers, Giacomo Bernardi {{< fa heart >}} at the University of California, Santa Cruz (USA). I conducted molecular biology lab work in his lab near the sea, where the weather was a perfectly sunny 20-25¬∞C every day.

There are only a handful of marine fish species that care for their newborn babies (though many care for their eggs), and two *Altrichthys* damselfish species are one of them. These fish stay with their babies in the same spot on the reef and ferociously protect them ‚Äì and you know how bold and fierce a damselfish can be! Giacomo wanted to determine whether brood parasitism occurred in these species. Since the babies look very similar to each other, even between the two *Altrichthys* species, we used microsatellite DNA markers to determine whether parents were caring exclusively for their own offspring or for babies from other parents as well. Long story short, there was indeed brood parasitism! You can find more information in the [PDF](pdfs/Tariel2019.pdf){target="_blank"}.

![](images/Altrichthys_alelia.jpg){fig-alt="Altrichthys alelia fish (parents and offspring) in a coral reef" fig-align="center"} 

To keep me busy at the end of my internship, Giacomo had me prepare samples for RAD sequencing, which resulted in two great publications.
